newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia drops hammer and sickle from passports.
newsitem.headline: Russia drops hammer and sickle from passports.

text.p: Five years after the collapse of the Soviet Union, Russians will finally be able to travel abroad with passports bearing their country's name and double-headed eagle emblem instead of the communist hammer and sickle.
The new Russian Federation passports will be issued from October 21 following a decree by President Boris Yeltsin, spokesman Sergei Yastrzhembsky told a news briefing on Friday.
Old Soviet travel documents are valid until their expiry dates. The re-introduction of the tsarist era eagle was delayed by wrangling in Moscow's communist-dominated parliament.

But the Soviet Union lives on in hundreds of other official documents. Travellers arriving in Russia still must state "Reasons for visiting the U.S.S.R". Thrifty bureaucrats are still using up vast stocks of stationery printed at a time when the demise of the communist empire seemed inconceivable.
